clean.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: Make sure you keep the wound clean.
Wipe that sink clean when you’re done.
As usual, she left her room clean and tidy  before going to school.
I want you to get those plates as clean as a whistle.
clean.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: having a clean appearance and habits
clean.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: containing or producing nothing that is dirty or harmful
clean.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: done in a fair or legal way
clean.translation[0].definitions[4].defi: showing that you have followed the rules
clean.translation[0].definitions[5].defi: not hiding any weapons or illegal drugs
clean.translation[0].definitions[5].exam: They searched him, but he was clean.
clean.translation[0].definitions[6].exam: Dave’s been clean for two years now.
clean.translation[0].definitions[7].defi: talk, jokes, behaviour etc that are clean are not offensive or about sex
clean.translation[0].definitions[7].note: clean living (=a way of life which is healthy and moral)
clean.translation[0].definitions[7].exam: Oh, don’t get mad – it’s just good clean fun!
Keep it clean (=do not offend people with what you say).
clean.translation[0].definitions[8].defi: a piece of paper that is clean has not yet been used
clean.translation[0].definitions[9].defi: having a smooth or regular edge or surface
clean.translation[0].definitions[9].exam: Use a clean simple typeface for signs.
clean.translation[0].definitions[10].exa: Add a little lemon juice to give the pasta a cool clean taste.
clean.translation[0].definitions[11].def: a clean movement in sport is skilful and exact
clean.translation[0].definitions[11].exa: He steadied his arm, hoping for a clean shot.
clean.translation[0].note_box[0].section: clean clothes
He had a shower and changed into clean clothes.
a clean shirt/sheet/towel etc
Where are all my clean socks?
clean hands
Make sure you have clean hands before you eat.
keep something clean
You should always keep your kitchen clean.
wipe something clean
He started to wipe the blackboard clean.
sweep/scrub something clean
She quickly swept the floor clean.
leave something clean
Please leave the apartment clean when you go.
spotlessly/scrupulously  clean
Hospitals must be kept scrupulously clean.
squeaky clean
I like my hair to be squeaky clean.
nice and clean
Their job is to keep the streets nice and clean.
clean and tidy
I insist my children keep their rooms clean and tidy.
neat and clean
Her kids were always neat and clean.
clean as a whistle
The place was clean as a whistle.
clean.translation[0].note_box[1].section: without any dirt or marks
They need clean water to drink.
I don’t have any clean clothes.
pure
water or air that is pure does not contain any dirt, pollution, or bacteria
I breathed in the pure mountain air.
sterile
completely clean, with no bacteria, and therefore safe for medical or scientific use
Place a sterile bandage on the wound.
sterile needles
spotless
completely clean – used mainly about rooms and clothes
Her kitchen is always spotless.
pristine
completely clean and new-looking
He wore a pristine white shirt.
immaculate
as clean and tidy as it is possible to be
The soldiers’ uniforms have to be immaculate.
spick and span
clean and tidy, especially after having just been cleaned
By the end of the day, the whole place was spick and span.
clean.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to remove dirt from something by rubbing or washing
clean.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: We clean the machines down at the end of each day.
He used a tissue to clean his fingerprints off the gun.
clean.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to clean a building or other people’s houses as your job
clean.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Anne comes in to clean twice a week.
clean.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to remove the inside parts of an animal or bird before cooking it
clean.translation[1].definitions[2].exam: Harry caught the fish and cleaned them himself.
clean.translation[1].note_box[0].section: to remove dirt from something
I need to clean the car.
Clean the mud off your shoes.
wash
to clean something with water and usually soap
She’s washing her hair.
There’s nowhere to wash your clothes.
wipe
to clean a surface with a cloth, often a wet cloth
Wipe the worktop when you’ve finished cooking.
scrub
to wash something by rubbing it hard, especially with a brush
They made her scrub the floor.
rinse
to remove dirt from something using water, especially after washing it with soap
Rinse your hair thoroughly after shampooing it.
cleanse
to clean your skin, using water or a special cream
There are many products available for cleansing your skin.
bathe
to clean a wound or a part of your body with water
Bathe the cut and put a plaster on it.
do the dishes
to wash plates and pans after a meal
Who’s going to help me do the dishes?
do the laundry
to wash clothes
On Tuesdays, he does the washing.
clean.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: used to emphasize the fact that an action or movement is complete and thorough
clean.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: Sorry, I clean forgot (=completely forgot) your birthday.
The thieves got clean away with $300,000 worth of equipment.
The car hit her with such force that she was lifted clean off the ground.
clean.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: a process in which you clean something
clean.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: The car needs a good clean.
clean.translation[4].definitions[0].defi: done in a fair or legal way, or showing that you have followed the rules or the law
clean.translation[4].definitions[0].exam: In ethical investment, investors try to buy shares in companies with a clean record.
His clean credit history will give him access to bank financing.
clean.translation[4].definitions[1].defi: clean products or industrial methods do not damage the environment
clean.translation[4].definitions[1].exam: clean vehicles such as electric cars and natural-gas buses
